How many of you guys feel disconnected? No matter what I do, how much I socialize or abstain from socializing, I feel like I am disconnected.

I can not relate to anyone I speak with, I can not get myself to care. A girl who just lost her fiance, someone taking about his favourite hobby, some guy who went from para to being able to walk again, it doesn´t matter, I can´t make myself care about any of it. Unless it is going to have an impact on my life, I could not care less.

I feel like I am windowshopping on an alien planet; not only am I only looking in and not being a part of any of it, I don´t even understand what "it" is.

I just drift through life, incapable of making any meaningful connection wit anyone but myself. the Closest I have come, is the internet, through its sheer volume the internet has made it possible for me to find people who I can connect with on some level.

That is why I lift, because I am the only person I know. The only meaningful impact I can have in my time alive, is an impact on myself, an impact on others is something I care naught for.

>>29534498
Well the issue anybody runs into when attempting to explain excess weight is that society is dynamic, and within the subcategories of a dynamic society you find even more variance between individuals.

I can't claim that people don't become fat due to poor lifestyle choices, I can't even claim that people don't become fat because they're lazy or lack self-discipline.

However, a multitude of evidence suggests a certain degree of environmental influence.
That overweight and obesity correlate strongly and reliably, even when compensating for other factors, with certain characteristics is telling.
>socio-economic status
>household facilities
>parental education
>location state-wide and city-wide
>ethnicity
>cultural upbringing
>method of transport (car, bus, bike, etc)

In western countries those who are poor, inadequately facilitated, uneducated, live on a bad side of town, live too far from a supermarket, aren't white, have migrated and don't own a car all show disproportionate amounts of overweight and obesity.

Excusing the extreme cases (prader-willi, for example), hamplanetry to the tune of 30% of the Australian >18y/o population simply can't be boiled down to a single individualistic factor; there is too much reliability in the environmental factors.

Hey fit,

new to liftan, been doing atg squats, but two days ago I started feeling a stinging pain in the area in pic related. It only came up about 3 hours after squatting and hasn't gone away since. I think it must be the hip flexors, since doing stretches for those alleviates the pain. What do, delay squatting and keep stretching the area? Could it be something else?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>29533177
Don't squat ass to grass. You probably don't have sufficient mobility, the vast majority of people don't. Go to the point where you can't maintain the natural lumbar lordosis anymore, and don't allow any lumbar flexion.

There's absolutely zero point in going beyond your own achievable range of motion, and there's nothing wrong with going to parallel. Switch to front squats as well.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>29533535
I agree with this guy except on the front squats. They're a nice accessory but can't replace heavy back squats.

>>29533534
yes. but you have to do this with caution because if done wrong, it will only exaggerate your problems more.
You must not just chill out in the hole for a few seconds sitting on your ass, you need to keep the tension in your abs and lower back (don't go so deep your back will round as the other guy has said).
Stretch before squatting if you can't get a proper position without, it can take 2 or 3 warumup sets until you get to depth. Always squat slowly and in a controlled manner for now, watch where your weight is on your foot and don't wobble around.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>29533423
I have this.
I've been lifting religiously for 15 years now and I avoid this problem by alternating barbell curls and dumbbell curls every arm workout. I've been to doctors and sports specialists and none of them have ever given me a solution other than "stop doing barbell curls". I don't know if it's just genetic or what, but if I do barbell curls or standing EZ bar curls for more than 2 workouts in a row, I get that tendonitis shit in my forearms.

Alternate using a bar and using dumbbells every other workout. I've avoided the forearm pain and my arms have gotten much bigger as a result. Only use dumbbells until the pain is entirely gone and then start alternating them.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>29533423
Hey OP I have this too, its actually tendonitis, which is an inflammation of the tendon in your forearm due to overuse.
Unfortunately yes, as everyone else is saying in this thread, the only way to deal with it is to stop inflaming the tendon, ie stop doing curls.
For me personally, curls where the hands are rotated to face upwards are the only exercise that cause this problem. Of course, YMMV.
Dumbbell hammer curls, narrow grip chin-ups, and just lots of back exercises in general can compensate for a lack of regular curls. It shouldn't be that big of a problem unless you're a pro bodybuilder.

threads.com: Should I resume losing weight or should I bulk up to get some actual muscle?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Don't bulk, you look like you're still 20-25% bf. Nice progress, but if you start bulking now it will all be for nothing.

The whole concept of bulking and cutting rests on the idea that when you're done your cut you're at a low bodyfat, so you can afford to go up a few percent bf when you bulk. If you're still pretty fat when you start to bulk, you'll just end up a fat fuck, and you'll lose all your gains in the year+ it takes you to diet down to 10%.

If your goal is to look good, always cut to 10% or lower before you start bulking.
